indicators.justification:
Since 1990, the National Statistics Office of Mongolia (NSO) used to collect GHG-related data from relevant sectors and publish the data on their web. The data between 1990 and 2015 contain detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions by disaggregating GHG emissions and removals by sector. A total of six sectors (including energy, agriculture, industry, land use, waste, and international flights) were used to estimate their GHG emissions and removals by using GHG-related 14 indicators and reporting them to the National Statistics Office. Although there are some open data that includes key elements, available data is outdated and limited in terms of contents, indicators, and disaggregation. The GHG-related 14 indicators have not been estimated since 2014(1). As stated in Mongolia's National Inventory Report, there is an emerging need to estimate GHG emissions. To collect data, the NSO or relevant ministries need to collect the data and prepare the estimates by applying the Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories (2). Except for Mongolia's National Inventory Report, there is a lack of publicly available reports and publications. Also, relevant stakeholders and procedures to obtain the data are unclear. 


Sources: 
(1). http://1212.mn/tables.aspx?TBL_ID=DT_NSO_2400_015V3
(2). Mongolia's National Inventory Report, 2017. https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/64281305_Mongolia-BUR1-1-NIR%20Mongolia%20082017.pdf

indicators.justification:
In Mongolia, the data on the company's beneficial ownership is not transparent. The National Statistics Office of Mongolia, in cooperation with the General Authority for State Registration, publishes data on the number of registered legal entities in Mongolia. The available data includes the number of total entities by location, a section of economic activities, type of ownership, and employment size(1). Mongolia has joined the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) in 2006. Since then, with the support of Extractive Industries Transparency Initiatives (EITI), the Government of Mongolia has started disclosing information about beneficial ownership in the extractive industry. Therefore, EITI Mongolia has collected and published information about the beneficial ownership in the extractive industry of Mongolia until 2017. In addition to that, Mongolia has joined the Open Government Partnership (OGP) in 2013. Accordingly, beneficial ownership disclosures became one of the major national commitments to the OGP(2). According to the amendments to the General Law on Taxation and Law on State Entity Registration made in 2019, all legal entities shall be obliged to register the ultimate beneficial owner information to the State Registration Authority within 01 January 2021. However, there is no publicly available data as of 30 August 2021. Therefore, there is no evidence or data that includes key elements of data requirements shown above. 

Sources: 
(1) Available data on Company, 2021 https://www.1212.mn/Stat.aspx?LIST_ID=976_L26&type=tables
(2) Mongolia Action Plan 2019-2021, 2019. https://www.opengovpartnership.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Mongolia_Action-Plan_2019-2021.pdf

indicators.justification:
The official website, www.1212.mn, Mongolian Statistical Information Services which is administered by National Statistical Office(NSO) provides basic information on birth and CRVS(1). Data published by NSO includes all key elements and meets the requirements of data including data openness, timing, and structure. According to the Law on Statistics, the NSO provides an opportunity to use the filters including location, time range, and other relevant variables where possible. Also, users are able to see the output as a table, line charts, column charts, area charts, bar charts, and pie charts without downloading data at all. It offers analysis options. Therefore, most of the datasets available can be shown by location and time (year and month). But specific variables including gender and age-related information are missing in Mongolia. 

Except for the NSO datasets, detailed information is also presented in the Health Indicator Reports developed annually by the Health Development Center(2). Although their publications and reports that present civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) information are publicly available, it's only available in printed versions not in machine-readable versions.

Sources: 
(1). Mongolian Statistical Information Services http://1212.mn/Stat.aspx?LIST_ID=976_L21&type=tables
(2). Mongolia Health Indicators-2020, http://www.hdc.gov.mn/media/uploads/2021-02/12_Sariin_medee.pdf

indicators.justification:
The official website, Mongolian Statistical Information Services (www.1212.mn) has been incorporated into the Health Development Center to provide the public with more data and reports. National Statistical Office(NSO) only publishes two capacity-related data including the number of hospital beds (1) and the number of health institutions(2) and as open data. The NSO publishes two capacity-related at the end of the year or at the beginning of the following year. Therefore, information about the capacity of the healthcare system cannot published in real-time. Moreover, there is a lack of detailed and publicly available information such as the number, type, and availability of beds, tests, vaccines, and devices at the level of individual facilities. Although health statistics are available and open to the public, health care facilities-related indicators and real-time healthcare personnel statistics are not publicly available as open data(3).

Regarding the COVID-19-focused donation statistics, the Ministry of Health created a separate and/or specific platform for presenting statistics and disclosing records of donation; however, relevant data are in a read-only mode not in a machine-readable version (4). In addition to that, information about the allocation of the donated products is not publicly disclosed. Although the information is available on this website, the data is not in machine-readable format either. 

Sources: 
(1) NSO-Health-Number of hospital beds, by type, location, and year. http://1212.mn/tables.aspx?TBL_ID=DT_NSO_2100_005V3- 
(2) NSO-Health- Number of health institutions, by location and year- http://1212.mn/tables.aspx?TBL_ID=DT_NSO_2100_008V3 
Number of health institutions by type and year. http://1212.mn/tables.aspx?TBL_ID=DT_NSO_2100_008V1 - 
(3). Mongolia Health Indicators-2020, http://www.hdc.gov.mn/media/uploads/2021-02/12_Sariin_medee.pdf
(4)Ministry of Health, COVID-19 Platform, https://covid19.mohs.mn/p/cat/post/50/

indicators.justification:
Mongolian Statistical Information Service(Dataset Records for National Statistical Office of Mongolia), in cooperation with the Ministry of Health, shares the daily updates of the COVID-19 pandemic on their website by showing data on the dashboard. But it's unable to download the dataset(1). Although COVID-19 related data including vaccination is shared with the public in a timely manner, it's not disaggregated by variables including gender, age, disability, etc. Therefore, this limitation hinders users from exploring data further(1). In addition to that, the Government of Mongolia has received financial and technical assistance from many stakeholders including donor organizations, international organizations, companies, and individuals. The Ministry of Health (MoH) has been sharing records of donations with the public and posting relevant data on their website, allocation of funds and products from donations are not transparent. National Statistical Office provides Coronavirus (COVID-19)-related data and statistics including cases, deaths, and hospitalization while MoH posts COVID-19 news, records, and guidance, in general(2). 

In general, there is a lack of disaggregated and machine-readable data that users can explore the data further. It also prevents making evidence-based decisions by ignoring the demographics and socio-economic characteristics of patients. Also, the access and proper disclosure of financial information are limited which may prevent citizens and patients to receive the need-based and urgent medical and public services due to the scarcity of resources.

Sources: 
(1) National Statistical Office-COVID-19 Dashboard-https://www.1212.mn/covid19.aspx
(2) Ministry of Health-Records of COVID-19 pandemic related donations: https://covid19.mohs.mn/p/cat/post/50/

indicators.justification:
The Agency of Land Affairs, Construction, Geodesy, and Cartography have created a platform that publishes data related to land affairs and relevant information(1). Although the platform is aimed at enabling access to data and information and offering online public services, data is not in machine-readable version but in read-only mode. Although there are several different platforms that publish land-related data and information, it's unable to download and explore land use information further because data is not in machine-readable version. Existing land use information is unavailable as open data. In terms of data timing, it varies across the types of land information. Due to the lack of transparent and open data related to land privatization and ownership, land conflicts still exist in Mongolia; thus, transparency of land privatization should be promoted and strengthened(2). 

Sources: 
(1) https://egazar.gov.mn
(2) Land Conflict and Solution Issues in Mongolia based on institutional approach, 2012, https://www.proquest.com/openview/ac4c73617474c5f1b42877439d2d4507/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=676307

In Mongolia, there are several information sources that can access land-related data including the National Land Information Database(1) and General Land Use Statistics(2) which are controlled by Agency for Land administration and management, geodesy and cartography, and the Land Database administered by the Environment Information Center(3).

indicators.justification:
There are three web portals that share data on the government budget and spending including https://shilendans.gov.mn, http://www.iltod.gov.mn, and https://publicinvestment.gov.mn. Three web portals are administered by the Ministry of Finance(1). But all of the government budget and spending in the three web portals are unavailable as open data as of October 2021. But the portal, 'http://iltod.mof.gov.mn/opendata' is under the construction.  Instead, the National Statistics Office of Mongolia (NSO) shares the historical and up-to-date data with the public. Also, the government budget and spending information are available as open data on the NSO's website(2). Overall, types of data related to the government budget and spending are varied and transparent to some extent. Also, data timing and openness are sufficient. However, there are some limitations related to the data formats and structure; therefore, users are not able to explore the data further and utilize it.  

Sources: 
(1). Ministry of Finance. https://mof.gov.mn/data_grid/budget/124/2017
(2) Government budget and spending, National Statistics Office of Mongolia. 
http://1212.mn/Stat.aspx?LIST_ID=976_L08&type=tables

As of 2021, there is no lobby registry in Mongolia. However, there is a lack of further evidence and information about their activities and details of lobby groups.

indicators.justification:
In accordance with laws on elections, the National Audit Office is publishing its financial audit reports. Although general information on political finance is available, political parties are not obliged to release details of donors and in-kind and non-financial support donated to each party or candidate by law. In accordance with election laws, each candidate shall disclose and submit details of their assets and liabilities(1).
Due to the lack of legal frameworks that require open data, there is no publicly available open data on political finance. Especially, there is no legal framework that requires political parties to publish political finance information as open data. The National Audit Office is making its financial audit reports public(2). Except for the audit reports in PDFs, there is a lack of an integrated database that provides full datasets that users could track change over time. Especially, political parties are not willing to publish their reports as open data voluntarily because it's not mandatory by law.


Sources: 
(1). The Law on Political Parties, 2005. https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/508
(2). The National Audit Office, Reports. 
https://audit.mn/?p=2599# Expenditure Reports of Candidates(https://audit.mn/?p=7174)
https://audit.mn/?p=2589 - Expenditure Reports of Political Parties (https://audit.mn/?p=9633)

indicators.justification:
Although the the Law on Legislation provides detailed guidance on how to organize public consultations and publish results, there is a lack of section that requires consultation results and data to be published as open data(1). There is an unified legal information system https://legalinfo.mn/ administered by the National Legal Institute(NLI) in Mongolia(2). NLI conducts online poll about proposed laws and administrative acts. The dashboards show the total number of votes for each choice. However, the data is only in 'read-only' mode. Therefore, users are not able to download and explore data further. Overall, public consultation data are not available as open data. 



Sources: 
(1). The Law on Legislation, 2015. https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/11119
(2). The Unified Legal Information System, National Legal Institute (under the Ministry of Justice and Internal Affairs) https://legalinfo.mn/en

indicators.justification:
According to the Law on Procurement of Goods, Works and Services with State and Local Funds, all procurement-related information must be transparent(1). The State Procurement Agency has been using the Public Procurement System of Mongolia that publishes all formal records of procurement of goods, works and services with state and local funds(2). Although the system is structured to publish very detailed records of all contracts and bids, data is incomplete and insufficient. Moreover, available data is not machine-readable format that users can explore data. Also, data timing and structure are questionable.  

Sources: 
1. The Law on Procurement of Goods, Works and Services with State and Local Funds    https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/493
2. Public Procurement System. (https://www.tender.gov.mn).

indicators.justification:
As stated in Section 3: Scope and Use of data of The State Policy on Open Data, the government will encourage stakeholders or users to reuse data(1). But there is a lack of guidance on how data could be used and relevant actions to encourage data reuse. Currently, government authorities are at the stage of putting emphasis on data collection and data publishing rather than data reuse. 

Since 2020, several hackathons are held between 2020 and 2021. Particularly, the Ministry of Education and Sciences(2), and the Ministry of Mining and Heavy Industry(3) have organized hackathons in cooperation with projects funded by international organizations including International Finance Corporation, World Bank, and Asian Development Bank, etc. B

Because the open data platform is newly established in 2020, the amount of open data is limited; thus, there is limited evidence to prove data reuse.

indicators.justification:
In Mongolia, several initiatives have been taken over the past few years. In 2019, the government of Mongolia passed resolution No. 73, the 'National Policy on E-Governance'(1). And the State Policy on Open Data is approved by the Communications and Information Technology Authority in 2019(2). Accordingly, the first open data portal has created in 2020 with the financial support of donor organizations(3). Particularly, existing platforms and initiatives are mainly funded by the projects funded by international organizations including World Bank. Although the Government of Mongolia has created an enabling legal and policy framework, the budget allocated for open data activities and the budget for its maintenance and expansion are critical. Because current initiatives are implemented with a loan provided for financing the open data program(4). 


Sources: 
(1). National Policy on E-governance, 2019. https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/14177/2/209503
(2) State Policy on Open Data, 2019. https://www.cita.gov.mn/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/%D0%9025-20190202-%D0%A2%D3%A9%D1%80%D3%A9%D3%A9%D1%81-%D0%BD%D1%8D%D1%8D%D0%BB%D1%82%D1%82%D1%8D%D0%B9-%D3%A9%D0%B3%D3%A9%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B9%D0%BD-%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B0%D1%80-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85-%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%8B%D0%BD-%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%BB%D1%8D%D0%BB-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85-%D1%82%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B9.pdf
(3) Open Data Portal, 2020. http://opendata.gov.mn/
(4) Open Data Readiness Assessment Mongolia, 2018. http://www.smart.gov.mn/wp-content/uploads/2019/02/ODRA_report_eng.pdf

indicators.justification:
National Policies including the State Policy on Open Data, apply to all national and local organizations. Therefore, all government organizations need to comply with the policy. However, due to the lack of financial and technical resources caused by the dependency on the project, 'Smart Government', funded by World Bank, city, regional, and local governments lack the capability to effectively manage data. Especially, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it was unable to take affirmative action at the local level and advance its open data initiatives. 

As indicated in the Open Data Platform, all government organizations are obliged by policy to publish data. Existing data are published by all ministries and grouped by ministries. But there is a lack of categories that highlight inputs from local organizations. Currently, local organizations are collecting and publishing(in printed versions) their data in their websites and transferring data to the ministries(2)

Therefore, there is a lack of evidence to present. Also, there is no permanent type of role responsible for data management in most 
public organizations(3).

Sources: 
(1).The State Policy on Open Data. 2019. https://www.cita.gov.mn/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/%D0%9025-20190202-%D0%A2%D3%A9%D1%80%D3%A9%D3%A9%D1%81-%D0%BD%D1%8D%D1%8D%D0%BB%D1%82%D1%82%D1%8D%D0%B9-%D3%A9%D0%B3%D3%A9%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B9%D0%BD-%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B0%D1%80-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85-%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%8B%D0%BD-%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%BB%D1%8D%D0%BB-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85-%D1%82%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B9.pdf
(2) Open Data Portal, 2020. http://opendata.gov.mn/

indicators.justification:
Overall, there is isolated evidence of the government supporting civil servants' training on data matters. Although the Government of Mongolia has approved the short and mid-term training programs for civil servants in 2019, the training program doesn't include any training on open government and open data(1).  

Instead, the Cabinet Secretary of the Government of Mongolia has organized several trainings on open data and IT-for government officers who work in IT-related departments. Especially, the Cabinet Secretary of Government of Mongolia has a dedicated division, Information Technology Division(2). The division is responsible for developing and running state information systems and digitizing public services. But trainings are mainly organized and supported by projects focused on the e-governance initiatives including Smart Government Project' funded by the World Bank. Trainings are organized with the support of the Smart Government Project at the request of the Government Cabinet Secretariat of Government of Mongolia and IT companies are organizing several trainings for government officers in IT-related departments(3).

Although there is a platform for government officers created by the MERIT project(4), the platform is inactive and has limited training course materials(5). The Cabinet Secretariat of the Government of Mongolia has uploaded contents of the training courses including ᠋Results-oriented policymaking and Monitoring and Evaluation (M᠊&E)' into the online training platform for government officers(6). Also, the Cabinet Secretariat of the Government of Mongolia has organized the training in cooperation with the MERIT project.

Sources: 
(1) Short term and Mid-term training program for civil servants, 2019, https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/14574
(2) Information Technology Division https://cabinet.gov.mn/sector/%d0%bc%d1%8d%d0%b4%d1%8d%d1%8d%d0%bb%d0%bb%d0%b8%d0%b9%d0%bd-%d1%82%d0%b5%d1%85%d0%bd%d0%be%d0%bb%d0%be%d0%b3%d0%b8%d0%b9%d0%bd-%d1%85%d1%8d%d0%bb%d1%82%d1%8d%d1%81-2
(3) News on Training https://cabinet.gov.mn/5438.html?lang=en
(4) Introduction to the MERIT project. http://portal.merit.mn/en/
(5) https://training-mongolia.thinkific.com
(6) https://training-mongolia.thinkific.com/courses/rbm

indicators.justification:
According to the amendment to the General Law on Taxation and Law on State Entity Registration made in 2019, all legal entities are required to submit their beneficial ownership data to the General Authority for State Registration. As stated in Section 17 of the Law on State Entity Registration, all entities are obliged to register their ultimate beneficial owners to keep their 'legal entity status. Therefore, regardless of their locality and sector, all new legal entities need to submit the form to register their entities. All entities need to upload their ultimate beneficial ownership data into the State taxpayer portal (1). However, there is no framework that requires or allows government authorities to publish data or requires all entities to disclose their beneficial ownership information publicly. Especially, there is a lack of provisions for the openness of collected data and procedures to publish the beneficial ownership data (2). 
 
Sources: 
(1) State taxpayer portal, 2020. https://etax.mta.mn
(2) Law on State Entity Registration, 2019, https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/13591

indicators.justification:
In 2019,  the "National Policy on E-Governance" is passed by the Government of Mongolia. As stated in Article 5: Action Plan of the National Policy on E-governance, e-governance platforms shall ensure the accessibility of the content and tools for people with disabilities and elders (1).  Also, the Government of Mongolia shall develop and set accessibility standards for all platforms. However, the State Policy on Open Data (2) is the only policy framework that regulates the issues related to data collection and publication, it misses specific requirements to make the data accessible to all including people with disabilities. It's apparent that the existing government's open data portal(3), is not accessible to people with disabilities. It proves that existing open data and e-government platforms are not meeting accessibility requirements.

Although several laws related to open data (including the draft law on the Protection of personal data and Law on Public data  ) are drafted and discussed, accessibility of data collection and publication are also missing components of those legal acts. In addition to that, expected new legal acts that are supposed to regulate issues related to the open data are not meeting accessibility requirements.

Sources:

indicators.justification:
Currently, the Law of Mongolia on Personal Privacy, especially, Article 6: Disclosure of information of the Law on Personal Privacy is serving as a regulatory framework for data-sharing (1). Although the State Policy on Open Data (2) is effective, there is a lack of guidance on how open data could be shared within stakeholders including not only government organizations but also different sectors. 

In May 2021, the draft law on the Protection of personal data(3) and Law on Public data are discussed publicly(4). The draft laws include various articles including data transfer. Therefore, the laws are expected to regulate issues in data sharing.

indicators.justification:
The Law of Mongolia on Personal Privacy (1) is enacted in 1995. As the main legislation, the law covers and considers five types of secrecy including secrecy of correspondence; secrecy of health information; secrecy of property; secrecy of family; and other secrecy, which is defined by laws. However, there is a lack of a framework that provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent or requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches. Also, it lacks a section that addresses algorithmic decision-making and the protection of data. Due to the insufficient available sections to regulate, the Draft Law on Protection of Personal Data was issued by parliament members, with an invitation for public comments(3) in February 2021. Although the draft law on the Protection of Personal Data is in the process of being approved, the new law includes various sections to fill the gaps in the existing law. 


Sources: 
(1) The Law of Mongolia on Personal Privacy, 1995, https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/537

indicators.justification:
As stated in Article 8 of Mongolia's Constitution(1), the Mongolian language shall be the official language of the State. In addition to Mongolia's Constitution, Article 6.1: Uses of the Language of the Mongolian Language law(2), all national and local government authorities shall use the Mongolian Language as it is an official language of the State. Although there is a lack of a dedicated or specific framework for language coverage related to open data, it should comply with the aforementioned two laws because data holders are government authorities. Accordingly, all government organizations use the Mongolian language as they publish open data. 

With regard to the provision for data quality, 'Section 4.6: Consistent and Regular Publication' of the State Policy on Open Data (3), indicates that the data shall be collected and published in a timely manner.

indicators.justification:
Open data is a novel term and concept in Mongolia; thus, currently, there is a lack of legal frameworks. Instead, two national policies including the State Policy on Open Data 2019 (1)and the National 'E-governance' program 2019-2021 (2) are enacted to regulate open data. The National E-governance program (2019-2021). Over the last few years, several stakeholders including the Communications and Information Technology Authority, National Statistics Office of Mongolia, and the General Authority for State Registration of Mongolia have been promoting the 'open data. In addition to that, the Cabinet Secretariat of the Government of Mongolia has been implementing the project, 'Smart Governance', in cooperation with World Bank(3). One of the main activities was creating the open-data portal. As a result, the government's open data portal(4) is created in 2020. The portal includes relevant sections that guide users including the definition of terms, licensing, and data formats. The aforementioned policies lack such regulations and detailed requirements as stated in the Open Data Readiness Assessment Report (5). 
In 2021, the Permanent Committee on the Innovation and E-governance and Permanent Committee on Public discussion on the 'Draft Law on Public Data' and the 'Draft Law on Protection of Personal Data, submitted by members of Parliament was held on 17 August 2021. Currently, the draft laws are in the process of being approved(6). 

Sources: 
(1) The State Policy on Open Data, 2019. https://www.cita.gov.mn/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/%D0%9025-20190202-%D0%A2%D3%A9%D1%80%D3%A9%D3%A9%D1%81-%D0%BD%D1%8D%D1%8D%D0%BB%D1%82%D1%82%D1%8D%D0%B9-%D3%A9%D0%B3%D3%A9%D0%B3%D0%B4%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B9%D0%BD-%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B0%D1%80-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BC%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85-%D0%B1%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BB%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%8B%D0%BD-%D1%87%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%BB%D1%8D%D0%BB-%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%85-%D1%82%D1%83%D1%85%D0%B0%D0%B9.pdf

indicators.justification:
There are several laws, regulations, and guidance that provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances. Especially, those legal acts aim at increasing transparency, public participation, and public oversight in the use of state and local government funds and assets. Legal acts include the Law on Budget, the Law on Law on Information Transparency and Right to Access Information, the Law on Procurement of Goods, Works and Services with State and Local Funds, and the Law on Glass Wallet.  In addition that, there are two main regulations (guidance) including 'Public Investment Project Planning, Budgeting, Monitoring, and Reporting' and 'Prioritizing and Evaluation Public Investment Projects'(1). Also, the enactment of the Law on Glass Account, advanced efforts toward fiscal transparency and citizen engagement. Especially, the Law on Glass Account resulted in the creation of two web portals for public investments(2) and public funds. The Ministry of Finance administers web portals and publishes data on government budgets, government spending, debt, and borrowing. Therefore, it's apparent that legal frameworks that provide a basis for collecting and publishing data on public finances are well-established in Mongolia. Although the two platforms are fully operational, some data are missing due to the lack of routine monitoring. Therefore,  enforcing is crucial in Mongolia. 

Sources: 
(1). A list of legal acts. Ministry of Finance. https://mof.gov.mn/data_grid/budget/124/2017
(2) Public Investment web portal. Ministry of Finance. https://publicinvestment.gov.mn/
(3) Public Fund web portal. Ministry of Finance. https://shilendans.gov.mn/

January 2012, the Parliament of Mongolia, the State Great Khural, adopted the Law on Regulating Public and Private Interests in Public Service and Preventing Conflicts of Interest(1). To enforce the law, the Procedure for registering and keeping private interest and assets declaration forms of public officials is enacted in 2018(2).  is. In accordance with the law, all public officials and candidates shall submit the declaration of assets and interests to the Independent Authority Against Corruption (IAAC). As a central law enforcement institution, IAAC is responsible for collecting declarations as structured data. Also, IAAC publishes data in their portal once they review and verify all declarations.  Also, IAAC administers the portal that publishes data on the interests and assets of public officials.

indicators.justification:
The Law on Political Parties and the three laws on Elections are the main regulatory frameworks in Mongolia. All laws require all parties to collect and publish their data on the campaign and party finance. In accordance with laws, political parties are obliged to make their report public but not its data on the website of the General Election Commission of Mongolia(1) Moreover, as stated in Article 20 of the Law on Political Parties, the National Audit Office shall investigate and audit the finance of the party annually(2). Accordingly, the National Audit Office is publishing its audit reports on its web. Although provisions for timing and structure are well-regulated, provisions for openness are not clear. As result, all documents and data are not machine-readable (PDFs and scanned). Because there is no open and available data, users or citizens are not able to explore and analyze it further.


Sources: 
(1) General Election Commission of Mongolia, https://www.gec.gov.mn/
(2). Law on Political Parties 
https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/508

indicators.justification:
Since its enactment in 2002, a total of 32 amendments are made to the Land Law of Mongolia(1). However, there is a lack of significant evidence or cases that have influenced the legal and policy framework with land data. Relevant news and articles focus on the introduction to the Land law or historical aspects of it rather than its impacts on society(2). Partially, it is caused by the lack of open data that all actors (media, CSOs, citizens) can access and explore further to identify issues related to the land. Therefore, there are isolated cases of actors or entities using this kind of data to influence policy in the interests of more equitable land tenure and use. 

Sources: 
(1) Land Law of Mongolia, 2002. https://legalinfo.mn/mn/detail/216
(2) Media News, "Land is the basis of Urban Development"  2018. https://ikon.mn/n/1dit

indicators.justification:
There is a dashboard that presents the government procurement data. Although users are able to view data or information, users are not able to download and explore data further due to the lack of machine-readable dataset(1). Moreover, available data is inconsistent and incomplete. Although records of some projects (or contracts) include various documents, some projects miss required information. Particularly, inconsistency of the data makes it difficult to compare or assess the contracts. Therefore, credibility of data also hinders the utilization of data. In addition to, the dashboard and data lack functions to present performance-related information. Therefore, users or citizens are unable to monitor the performance of each contract (or project). Currently, there is a lack of apparent evidence that could show the utilization of the procurement data in all sectors. 

Source: 
(1). Public Procurement System of Mongolia.https://www.tender.gov.mn/en/index/
